value:
A measure of a unit's overall power.
Rises by 1 when a unit levels up.

Experience points. A unit will level
up after collecting a set amount.

A unit is defeated if its Hit
Points reach 0.

The higher a unit's Attack,
the more damage it will
inflict on foes.

A unit will attack twice if its
Speed is at least 5 more
than its foe's Speed.

The higher a unit's Defense is, the less
damage it takes from physical attacks
(swords, axes, lances, etc.).

The higher a unit's Resistance is, the less
damage it takes from magical attacks
(spells, staves, breath effects, etc.).
Skill Points. Spent to obtain skills.

Weapon triangle adv.: Atk +20%
Weapon triangle disadv.: Atk -20%

Sword. Physical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Def.

Lance. Physical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Def.

Axe. Physical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Def.

Bow. Physical weapon. Range: 2.
Damage reduced by target's Def.
Extra damage to flying foes.

Dagger. Physical weapon. Range: 2.
Damage reduced by target's Def.
Can temporarily reduce target's stats.

Red Tome. Magical weapon. Range: 2.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Blue Tome. Magical weapon. Range: 2.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Green Tome. Magical weapon. Range: 2.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Staff. Magical weapon. Range: 2 (attack
only). Damage reduced by target's Res.

Red Breath. Magical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Blue Breath. Magical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Green Breath. Magical weapon. Range: 1.
Damage reduced by target's Res.

Infantry unit. Can move two spaces.
Slowed by forests, etc.
Armored unit. Can move one space.

Cavalry unit. Can move three spaces.
Cannot move through forests.

Flying unit. Can move two spaces. Ignores
forests, mountains, rivers, etc., when moving.

Allies earn Hero Merit for battles that they
survive. After earning enough, they'll give
you Hero Feathers via the Home screen.

Foot soldier who uses a
sword. Average ability.

Armored knight skilled with
a sword. Moves slowly.

Mounted soldier who uses a sword.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

Pegasus rider with a sword. Flies over rivers
and mountains. Weak against bows.

Foot soldier who uses a
lance. Average ability.

Armored knight skilled with
a lance. Moves slowly.

Mounted soldier who uses a lance.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

Pegasus rider with a lance. Flies over rivers
and mountains. Weak against bows.

Foot soldier who uses an
axe. Average ability.

Armored knight skilled with
an axe. Moves slowly.

Mounted soldier who uses an axe.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

Pegasus rider with an axe. Flies over rivers
and mountains. Weak against bows.

Foot soldier who uses a
bow. Average ability.

Mounted soldier who uses a bow.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

A thief who uses daggers, which
lower an enemy's stats.

A wielder of red magic
with average ability.

Mounted soldier who uses red magic.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

A wielder of blue magic
with average ability.

Mounted soldier who uses blue magic.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

A wielder of green magic
with average ability.

Mounted soldier who uses green magic.
Moves far, but can't enter forests.

A unit that uses staves to heal and
hinder. Average ability.

Mounted unit that uses staves to heal and
hinder. Moves far, but can't enter forests.

A masked knight whose identity
and motives are a mystery.

Imperial princess of the Emblian Empire.
Uses Heroes against the Askran Kingdom.

Prince of Altea who fights for his homeland
and deeply values his friends. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A mercenary who was once a slave gladiator.
Serves Princess Caeda of Talys. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Skilled fighter known as the Scarlet Sword.
Prefers his blade to do the talking. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

The son of Eliwood, Marquess of Pherae
and talented leader of its army. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A woman who travels in search of the best
swordplay opponents anywhere. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A woman who grew up on the plains before
learning she is nobility of Caelin. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

A prince of Ylisse and descendant of the
Hero-King. Leads the Shepherds. Appears
in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A princess and daughter of Chrom who
traveled to her past to prevent apocalypse.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A skilled swordsman of Regna Ferox who
is oddly skittish around women. Appears
in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A dancer who travels widely and is quite
gifted, despite extreme shyness. Appears
in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A Hoshidan prince raised in Nohr. Fights on
his chosen path with the divine blade Yato.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

The eldest prince of Hoshido, who
wields the legendary blade Raijinto.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A noble who is skilled with the katana.
One of Sakura's retainers. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

A coarse, yet caring, samurai of Hoshido.
One of Takumi's retainers. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

A mysterious man with a flair for dancing
and flirting. One of Xander's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A mysterious woman devoted to service.
One of Camilla's retainers. Snarky.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A prince of Askr and member of the
Order of Heroes. Kind and serious,
and eager to maintain peace.

An armored knight of Altea who served as
Marth's shield. Very sincere. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

King of Bern. Once a kindhearted boy who
became disillusioned with humanity. Wants
his world to be ruled by dragons. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Altean cavalier known for recklessness.
Rode with Abel in service of Marth. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A sincere noble of Pherae. His friends Lyn
and Hector serve him loyally. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

A kind but slightly scatterbrained knight
who serves with the Shepherds.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Nohrian prince respected for his military
prowess. Wields the divine blade Siegfried.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Princess of Talys who's as talented as she
is charming. Marth's betrothed. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Eldest of three sisters who are pegasus
knights for Macedon. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A farm boy from a country village in
the Halidom of Ylisse. Handy and hardy.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Lance wielder who loves fashion and hates
Nohr. One of Takumi's retainers. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

An enchanting princess raised in Hoshido
who sings in battle to help her allies.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A princess of Askr and Alfonse's
sister. Cheerful and loves making
friends—especially with Heroes.

Armored knight of Ostia. Intent on mastering
defense, despite feeling awkward in armor.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A gentle knight with great strength and
devotion. One of Elise's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Veteran knight of Altea who protected
Marth since he was young. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Altean cavalier known for his sensibility.
Rode with Cain in service of Marth. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A knight who's devoted to his motherland,
Grust. Wields the lance Gradivus. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A member of the Shepherds who is serious
about becoming a great knight. Appears in
Fire Emblem Awakening.

A cavalier of Nohr who massacres foes with
childlike glee. One of Xander's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Middle of three sisters who are pegasus
knights for Macedon. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Youngest of three sisters who are
pegasus knights for Macedon. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A trainee of the Pegasus Knights of Ilia.
Cheerful and optimistic. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Youngest of three sisters who are
Pegasus Knights of Ilia. Shy, gentle
girl who loves animals. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

The sole survivor of Ylisse's pegasus
knights. Humble and supremely talented.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Hoshidan princess who prefers battles over
court life. Excels at watching over others.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Sky Knight of Hoshido who aims for
perfection. One of Sakura's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Warrior of Talys who works for Ogma and
has been a pirate and woodcutter. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

An outpost warrior who went on a journey to
find his beloved daughter, Fir. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A noble heir whose true name is Raymond.
Works as a mercenary to enact revenge.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

Guardian of the Nabata Desert and Arcadia,
where dragons and humans live in harmony.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

A sworn ally of justice with uncannily bad
luck. One of Elise's retainers. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

A veteran fighter who leads the Order of
Heroes. Alfonse and Sharena's commander.

Princess of Gra, a failing realm. Feels the
heavy weight of her responsibility. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Eliwood's friend and brother of the Marquess
of Ostia. Prefers action to court formality.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

A knight who serves the royal house of
Ylisse and helps lead Chrom's Shepherds.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Veteran knight of Nohr. One of Corrin's
retainers. Extremely strict. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

Princess of Macedon who took up arms
against her brother, Michalis. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

King of Macedon who had great ambitions
for his country. Murdered his father.
Brother to Minerva and Maria. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

One of three Wyvern Generals of Bern.
Conceited and vainglorious. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Wyvern-riding fighter in Virion's noble house.
Thinks her wyvern Minerva is adorable.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Princess of Nohr who dotes on her
sibling Corrin and is merciless to foes.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Wyvern-riding assassin who seems devoid
of emotion. One of Camilla's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Altean archer who is masterful with his bow.
Looks younger than he actually is. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Archanean archer thought to be the best on
his continent. A skilled strategist. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Rightful ruler of Rosanne in Valm who has
a tendency for wit and puffery. Appears
in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Prince of Hoshido who wields the divine
bow Fujin Yumi. Prickly at times.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Hoshidan archer who is either fearless or
daydreaming. One of Hinoka's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Nohrian scoundrel who wags his saucy
tongue at everyone. One of Leo's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Happy-go-lucky spy who's actually quite sly.
Serves Hector, brother of the Marquess of Ostia.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

Thief of Ylisse known for his nimble hands and
sweet tooth. Hides sweets in his pockets.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A maid of Nohr who's eager to do good work
yet often bungles. One of Corrin's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A butler of Nohr who's superb at his work yet
dislikes serving anyone but his liege, Corrin.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A severe ninja of Hoshido. Has a twin brother
named Kaze. One of Ryoma's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A ninja of Hoshido who is ready to lay down her
life for her liege. One of Ryoma's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A noble of Ostia with a natural gift for magic.
Roy's friend since childhood. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Wielder of dark magic. A scornful loner with
a troubled past as an orphan. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A shaman of Nabata who has lived a sheltered
life away from other people. Sees the future.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

A mage from Plegia with a dark side and a
possessive streak, especially with Robin.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A dark mage of Plegia with a bright grin
and a taste for the gruesome in battle.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A talented Nohrian prince who wields
the divine tome Brynhildr. Appears
in Fire Emblem Fates.

Daughter of Pontifex Miloah from Archanea.
Inherited the light tome Aura. Wants to
avenge her father's death. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A tactician of Ylisse and Chrom's close ally.
Lost memory of his life before meeting Chrom.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A mysterious man who tends to be
overly theatrical. One of Leo's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A cruel member of the Black Fang assassins.
Lends her service only to someone truly perfect.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

Wind mage who studied in Khadein, known for its
magical school. Marth's childhood friend. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

A kindhearted member of the Black Fang
assassins. Longed to help her mother. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

A tactician of Ylisse and Chrom's close ally.
Lost memory of her life before meeting Chrom.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Mage General of Etruria. Taught Roy and
Lilina when they were young. Appears in
Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Humble priest of Talys who likes a quiet life.
Despises battle, preferring to heal allies. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Shadow Dragon and the
Blade of Light.

Princess of Macedon. Younger sister of Minerva
and Michalis, whom she loves dearly. Appears
in Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Cleric who thinks less of others, more of herself.
Serves Hector, brother of the Marquess of Ostia.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade.

Princess of Ylisse's royal house and Chrom's
younger sister. Determined to prove herself.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Princess of Hoshido who is a gentle healer.
Struggles with her shyness. Appears in
Fire Emblem Fates.

A monk of Hoshido with a curious sense
of humor. One of Hinoka's retainers.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

Noble daughter of Count Reglay of Etruria. Fond
of her brother, Klein. Has lived a privileged life.
Appears in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Princess of Nohr who adores her siblings. A bit
childish, but has a pure heart and keen eyes.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A young Divine Dragon once put into a timeless
sleep to keep her dragon impulses in check.
Now longs for human company. Appears in
Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

Known as the Voice of the Divine Dragon.
Has lived for ages. Once friends with Marth.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

Manakete who travels with Chrom's group. Looks
young but truly is over a thousand years old.
Appears in Fire Emblem Awakening.

A Hoshidan princess raised in Nohr. Fights on
her chosen path with the divine blade Yato.
Appears in Fire Emblem Fates.

A surviving Divine Dragon with the nature of a
child and very little life experience. Appears
in Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade.

Effective against flying foes. If unit’s HP ≥ 50%,

target's HP is ≤ 50%, the lower the target's HP,
the more HP is restored. (Minimum of 7 HP.)
Unit and target ally swap spaces.

Unit moves 1 space away from target ally. Ally

Target ally moves to opposite side of unit.

If unit has weapon-triangle advantage, boosts Atk
by 10%. If unit has weapon-triangle disadvantage,
reduces Atk by 10%.

If unit has weapon-triangle advantage, boosts Atk

Unit can counterattack regardless of foe's range.
Unit can counterattack regardless of foe's range.

If unit initiates combat, target foe moves 1 space
away after combat.

If unit initiates combat, unit and target foe swap
spaces after combat.

If unit initiates combat, unit moves 1 space away
after combat. Target foe moves to unit's previous
space.

If unit’s HP ≥ 75%, unit can move through foes’
spaces.

If unit’s HP ≥ 50%, unit can move through foes’
spaces.

If unit’s HP ≥ 25%, unit can move through foes’
spaces.

If unit's HP ≥ 90%, foes cannot move through
spaces adjacent to unit. (Does not affect foes with
Pass skills.)

If unit's HP ≥ 70%, foes cannot move through
spaces adjacent to unit. (Does not affect foes with
Pass skills.)

If unit's HP ≥ 50%, foes cannot move through
spaces adjacent to unit. (Does not affect foes with
Pass skills.)

If an ally's HP ≤ 30%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to that ally.

If an ally's HP ≤ 40%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to that ally.

If an ally's HP ≤ 50%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to that ally.

If unit’s HP ≤ 30%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to any ally.

If unit’s HP ≤ 40%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to any ally.

If unit’s HP ≤ 50%, unit can move to a space
adjacent to any ally.

If unit’s HP ≤ 25% and foe initiates combat, unit
can counterattack before foe’s first attack.

If unit’s HP ≤ 50% and foe initiates combat, unit
can counterattack before foe’s first attack.

If unit’s HP ≤ 75% and foe initiates combat, unit
can counterattack before foe’s first attack.

If unit’s HP ≤ 25% and unit initiates combat, unit
can make a follow-up attack before foe can
counterattack.

If unit’s HP ≤ 50% and unit initiates combat, unit
can make a follow-up attack before foe can
counterattack.

If unit’s HP ≤ 75% and unit initiates combat, unit
can make a follow-up attack before foe can
counterattack.

If unit initiates combat against a foe that
can counter and unit's HP ≤ 30%, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit initiates combat against a foe that
can counter and unit's HP ≤ 40%, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit initiates combat against a foe that
can counter and unit's HP ≤ 50%, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit’s HP ≥ 90% and foe initiates combat, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit’s HP ≥ 80% and foe initiates combat, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit’s HP ≥ 70% and foe initiates combat, unit
makes a guaranteed follow-up attack.

If unit's HP ≥ 90%, unit and foe cannot make a
follow-up attack.

If unit's HP ≥ 70%, unit and foe cannot make a
follow-up attack.

If unit's HP ≥ 50%, unit and foe cannot make a
follow-up attack.

There are four movement types for
units: Infantry, Armored, Flier, and
Cavalry.

Infantry and armored units may look
similar, but they can move different
distances in battle.

Armored units have superior defense.

However, they can move only
1 space at a time.

Flier units can move 2 spaces. They
can also fly over oceans and
mountains.

However, they are weak to arrows.

Cavalry units can move 3 spaces.

However, they cannot traverse forests.

Want your units to battle
automatically? Use the Auto-Battle
option.

During battle, open the menu in the
lower left and select Auto-Battle.

The Auto-Battle option lets your
allies battle automatically.

During battle, press the
Auto-Battle button to activate it.

To change the positions of your allies
before the fight begins, tap the Swap
Spaces button at the bottom of the
screen.

You can keep making changes up until
someone completes an action.

You can earn Orbs and other items
by clearing quests.

Tap the fountain in the lower right
of the Home screen to check the
latest quests.

Make your Heroes stronger by saving
up SP and using it to learn new skills.

To learn new skills, select Learn Skills
in the Allies menu.

Make your Heroes stronger by saving
up SP and using it to learn new skills.

To learn new skills, select Learn
Skills under Ally Growth in the Allies
menu.

Want another way to teach your
Heroes skills? Try using Inherit Skill.

Inherit Skill is located under Advanced
Growth in the Allies menu.

Want another way to teach your
Heroes skills? Try using Inherit Skill.

Inherit Skill is located under Ally
Growth in the Allies menu.

Use Unlock Potential to raise your
allies to 5★ units.

Unlock Potential is located under
Advanced Growth in the Allies menu.

Use Unlock Potential to raise your
allies to 5★ units.

Unlock Potential is located under
Ally Growth in the Allies menu.

Combat animations can be turned off.

During battle, open the menu in the
lower left, and then select Settings to
make changes.

You can upgrade your castle!
Renovate its interior to change its
style, and you'll gain more EXP
during battle.

Select Upgrade Castle in the Shop
menu to check your options.

The team in the leftmost slot under
Edit Teams is the one that represents
you. This is the team used in the
Arena, too.

The unit in the leftmost position of this
team is your leader.

If you have a weapon advantage, you
can do more damage. You'll notice
the numbers appear bigger when
you do.

You can check weapon advantages
for the three colored types in the
lower right of the screen during battle.

If you see an icon appear above an
enemy during battle, move carefully.
This lets you know if an ally is effective
against a particular enemy.

Bows are effective against fliers.
Other weapons, like Falchion,
are effective against other enemies.

You must link a Nintendo Account if
you wish to access your data from
another device. If you delete the app
without linking, you will not be able to
recover your save data. You can link
an account from Account Management
on the Misc. screen.

The Training Tower is the most
efficient place for leveling allies.

You can earn more EXP and SP
there than you can from the
Arena or other cleared maps.

The Training Tower is the most
efficient place for leveling allies.
You can tap the refresh button
to the left of the ? to change the
enemies you'll face.
Think about what enemies your
team has an advantage over
before going into battle.

Strengthen your allies through
Ally Support! Allies who are
partnered up will gain a stat
boost when they fight near
each other.

You can find Ally Support
under Advanced Growth in the
Allies menu.

Strengthen your allies through
Ally Support! Allies who are
partnered up will gain a stat
boost when they fight near
each other.

You can find Ally Support under
Interact with Allies in the Allies
menu.
